name: Lava River Cave
description: Lava River Cave is a mile-long lava tube located in the Coconino National Forest. This unique geological feature offers an exciting underground adventure for families. The cave maintains a cool temperature year-round, making it perfect for hot summer days. Bring flashlights and layers - it's cold inside!
shortDescription: Mile-long lava tube cave perfect for underground family adventures.
address: FR 171B, Coconino National Forest, Flagstaff, AZ 86001
topPickReason: A unique underground adventure that kids remember forever - naturally cool on hot summer days.
tips: Bring at least 2 flashlights per person
Wear warm layers - it's around 40Â°F inside
Sturdy shoes required - the floor is uneven
Not recommended for young children due to terrain

name: Red Mountain
description: Red Mountain is a collapsed volcanic cinder cone with stunning red and orange rock formations. A short hike leads into the crater where kids can explore the colorful hoodoos and unique geological features. It's like walking on another planet!
shortDescription: Collapsed cinder cone with otherworldly red rock formations to explore.
address: US-180, 25 miles north of Flagstaff, AZ
tips: Best in morning or evening light for photos
Bring water - no facilities
Stay on trail to protect formations
About 25 minutes from downtown Flagstaff

name: Sunset Crater Volcano National Monument
description: Sunset Crater is Arizona's youngest volcano, last erupting around 1085 AD. The visitor center offers interactive exhibits about volcanoes, and several trails let families explore the lunar-like landscape of cinder cones and lava flows. It's an educational adventure through volcanic history.
shortDescription: National monument featuring Arizona's youngest volcano with interactive exhibits.
tips: Combined pass available with Wupatki
Junior Ranger program available
Lava Flow Trail is wheelchair accessible
Bring layers - can be windy

name: Walnut Canyon National Monument
description: Walnut Canyon preserves ancient cliff dwellings of the Sinagua people. The Island Trail descends into the canyon past 25 cliff dwelling rooms, offering an immersive look at how people lived here 800 years ago. It's a memorable history lesson in a beautiful setting.
shortDescription: Ancient cliff dwellings with trails past 800-year-old Sinagua homes.
tips: Island Trail has 240 steps - moderate fitness needed
Rim Trail is easier for younger kids
Junior Ranger program available
Allow 2+ hours for the Island Trail

name: Flagstaff Extreme Adventure Course
description: Flagstaff Extreme is an aerial adventure park set among the tall ponderosa pines at Fort Tuthill. Multiple courses of varying difficulty let participants zip, climb, and swing through the treetops. There's a kids' course for younger adventurers and challenging adult courses.
shortDescription: Treetop adventure course with zip lines and climbing for all skill levels.
tips: Reserve online in advance
Kids course for ages 5-7
Closed-toe shoes required
Allow 2-3 hours for full experience

name: Lowell Observatory
description: Lowell Observatory is where Pluto was discovered! This historic observatory offers daytime tours, interactive exhibits, and nighttime telescope viewing. Kids love looking through the historic Clark Telescope and learning about the universe. The Giovale Open Deck Observatory features state-of-the-art telescopes.
shortDescription: Historic observatory where Pluto was discovered, with interactive exhibits and telescope viewing.
address: 1400 W Mars Hill Rd, Flagstaff, AZ 86001
tips: Evening programs offer telescope viewing
Dress warmly for nighttime visits
Check for special events and programs
Flagstaff's dark skies provide amazing viewing
